repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

did.abstract: This collection contains issues of The Crisis, the official publication of the NAACP, and other materials created by the NAACP, as well as other publications and ephemera concerning the civil rights of African Americans and related issues.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of James H. Kelly, 2018, accession number MS-2019-031.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in two series: The Crisis; and Ephemera and related materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Crisis is the official publication of the NAACP. It was founded in 1910 by W.E.B. Du Bois, one year after the founding of the NAACP. The magazine's original purpose was to record the difficulties Black Americans faced finding housing, employment, and educational opportunities, and encountering police brutality and other issues arising from systemic racism. By the end of its first decade, The Crisis had achieved a monthly circulation of 100,000 copies.

The Crisis records the views and campaigns of the NAACP. The magazine has historically included editorials criticizing Woodrow Wilson's policy of mandated segregation in federal offices, the failure of the Dyer Anti-lynching bill to pass in the Senate in the 1920's, and exhibitions of the D.W. Griffith film "The Birth of a Nation," which idealizes the Klu Klux Klan. Additionally, advertisements in the magazine promote opportunities for education, jobs, and real estate. Often, the advertisements reflect the values of the editor at the time; for example, under Du Bois' editorship, advertisements about education were the most prevalent.

The magazine also played a crucial role in supporting writers of the Harlem Renaissance after the appointment of Jessie Redmon Fauset as literary editor. Fauset guided several prominent Black authors in the early stages of their careers, including Arna Bontemps, Langston Hughes, and Countee Cullen.

The Crisis struggled to maintain its circulation after Fauset left the magazine in 1926. Additionally, in 1934, Du Bois left his position as editor after disputes with board members in the NAACP over his opinions on Black separatism. Though the magazine is best known for its years of editorship under Du Bois, The Crisis was praised for its coverage of the civil rights movements during the 1960's, and as of 2018, continues to publish articles which educate readers on challenges facing communities of color.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Crisis Magazine, 1916 -- 2009. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of this collection was completed by Leah Edelman and Uella Rodriguez in 2018. Materials were placed in archival boxes and folders and arranged chronologically. A folder-level inventory and series-level descriptions were created, and the finding aid was also created at the time of processing.
In April 2021 this finding aid was reviewed for offensive description by Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt. The word "Black" was capitalized when used to refer to an identity or race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains issues of The Crisis, the official publication of the NAACP, from 1929 through 2002. This collection also contains publications, a poster, and other documents created by the NAACP, and other publications and ephemera concerning the civil rights of African Americans and related issues.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproduction and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Any intellectual property rights that the donor possesses have been transferred to Tufts University.
